messageBody:
Mariano Cortesi (Cono) wrote:

> Are the configuration files of frameworks we use everyday needed to be
> tested?

Lately, I have been trying to do so. My framework of interest currently
is Eclipse. I use test-driven development, and my current rule is that
if I have to change a configuration file to get a system test to work,
I'll write a unit test for that configuration file change. I've found
the resulting tests most useful for regression testing--the most common
configuration bugs, in my experience so far, are not ignorant human
changes, but source control misuse or other mistakes that result in
out-of-date configuration files.

> My concrete problem is that I want to test hibernate configuration.
> I have two ideas on how to do this:
>
> 1. Use dbunit, hsqldb to make some basic operations over my
> persistent classes. This way I'm pretty sure they are correctly mapped.
> 2. I somehow manage to test the configuration files.

I've been using option #2. Rather than write my own XML-parsing code, I
figured out how to drive the tests using the lowest 1.5 layers of
Eclipse's own configuration parsing code. This has the strong
advantage that my tests see the configuration files the way Eclipse
does. If I tested closer to the actual XML, I would insulate myself
from bugs in Eclipse, but I've found a lot more bugs in recently-changed
configuration files than in Eclipse's parsing code. If I tested further
back (closer to your option #1), I'd be getting closer to integration
tests, which would make it harder to figure out whether failures were
due to the configuration, or some aspect of the things being configured.

The big downside is the up-front cost of this approach. It took the
better part of a day to understand the Eclipse parsing code well enough
to reuse it, and I had to resort to some evil-looking tricks, because
the parser has an astounding number of dependencies on the rest of
Eclipse that I had to stub out. Once I'd written two tests, though, the
rest have come fast and furious.

The other downside is a bit of cognitive dissonance. It feels like I
could get to the point where I was basically writing the same thing in
two places, first in the test, then in the configuration file itself.
So far, I don't feel that fear has born itself out, so I try to ignore it.

Share and Enjoy,

David Saff
